s.text: (Students, of course, are in some sense a captive market, forced to buy the books their professors assign.
From the farmer's point of view, the opportunity to buy infertile seeds can be a great boon.
But in the face of considerable public pressure, Monsanto has agreed to stop developing infertile seeds.
When I wrote my first textbook, the publisher wanted to combat the second-semester used book market by sewing a $100 bill into the binding of every 100 th book.
And the logic is still wrong when applied to textbooks, because the sale price for a book that can be resold is likely to be far higher than the price of a book designed to lose its value.
Every student would tear his book apart to see if he'd won.
